skill.name: tool-selection-framework
skill.description:
Design systematic decision frameworks for selecting appropriate AI tools (Claude Code vs Gemini CLI)
based on context requirements, codebase size, reasoning depth needs, and task complexity. Use this
skill when starting projects with unclear tool requirements, optimizing context-constrained workflows,
or designing multi-phase strategies that leverage multiple tools' strengths. This skill helps match
tool capabilities to task characteristics, preventing wasted context and ensuring optimal resource
allocation.
skill.summary: Design systematic decision frameworks for selecting appropriate AI tools (Claude Code vs Gemini CLI)...
skill.author: 92Bilal26

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and decision frameworks. No executable code, scripts, network calls, filesystem access, or external command execution. Contains only instructional content for tool selection methodology.

content.value_statement: Choosing the wrong AI tool wastes context, increases costs, and slows development. This framework provides systematic decision criteria to match tool capabilities (Claude Code, Gemini CLI) to your specific task requirements, ensuring optimal resource allocation and project success.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes codebase size to recommend appropriate context window (up to 500K+ lines)
Distinguishes between exploration tasks (broad understanding) and focused implementation
Evaluates reasoning depth requirements (architectural decisions vs pattern matching)
Designs multi-phase workflows using Gemini for exploration and Claude Code for implementation
Balances cost, performance, and time sensitivity based on project constraints
Creates decision matrices matching tool capabilities to task characteristics
limitations: Does not execute code or interact with development environments directly
Cannot access your codebase to perform measurements without explicit prompts
Provides recommendations only; final tool selection remains with user
Framework assumes Claude Code (200K context) and Gemini CLI (2M context) as primary tools

use_cases.title: Large codebase tool strategy
use_cases.description: Design multi-phase workflows for codebases exceeding 500K lines using Gemini exploration followed by Claude Code implementation.

use_cases.title: Context optimization planning
use_cases.description: Evaluate project requirements to select tools that maximize reasoning depth while staying within context budgets.

use_cases.title: Cost-effective tool selection
use_cases.description: Match small-to-medium projects (<100K lines) to Claude Code for lower cost without sacrificing capability.

prompt_templates.title: Basic project assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: My project has approximately [X] lines of code. I need to [task description]. Help me select the appropriate AI tool using the framework.

prompt_templates.title: Large codebase exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: I am working with a [X]-line legacy codebase that I do not understand. I need to [goal]. Design a multi-phase workflow using Gemini for exploration and Claude Code for implementation.

prompt_templates.title: Time-critical decisions
prompt_templates.prompt: Production is down. I have a [X]-line codebase and need to fix a specific bug quickly. Should I use Claude Code or Gemini? Recommend based on time-critical workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Cost optimization review
prompt_templates.prompt: I am working on a [X]-line project with limited budget. My task is [description]. Help me minimize cost while still completing the work effectively using the framework.

output_examples.input: My 800K-line legacy system needs authentication migration. I need deep reasoning for security-critical changes. Help me select tools.
output: RECOMMENDATION: Multi-phase workflow (Gemini explore â†’ Claude Code implement)
RATIONALE: 800K lines exceeds Claude Code 200K context, but security migration requires deep reasoning Claude Code provides

WORKFLOW: Phase 1 (Gemini): Load full codebase, map authentication across all modules, generate 15K-token summary. Phase 2 (Claude Code): Load summary, implement migration module-by-module with deep security reasoning
EXPECTED OUTCOME: Comprehensive system understanding from Gemini + security-focused implementation from Claude Code

best_practices: Measure codebase size using tools like 'cloc' before making tool selection decisions
Default to Claude Code for most tasks under 100K lines; Gemini is overkill for small projects
Document tool selection rationale in decisions.md for future reference and team alignment
anti_patterns: Using Gemini CLI for a 10K-line project (wastes context, increases cost, slower iteration)
Using Claude Code to explore a 1M-line monolith (insufficient context causes frustration)
Ignoring task type and using a single tool for both exploration and implementation phases

faq.question: What codebase size triggers Gemini CLI selection?
faq.answer: Codebases over 500K lines require Gemini for exploration due to Claude Code's 200K context limit. For 50K-500K lines, task type determines tool.

faq.question: When should I use Claude Code over Gemini CLI?
faq.answer: Use Claude Code for focused implementation, deep reasoning (architecture, security), time-critical tasks, and codebases under 100K lines.

faq.question: Can I use both tools in a single project?
faq.answer: Yes. Multi-phase workflow is recommended for large codebases: Gemini for exploration, Claude Code for implementation. See Algorithm 2 in the framework.

faq.question: How does this framework handle cost optimization?
faq.answer: Claude Code is lower cost per session for smaller contexts. Use Claude Code for iterative work, Gemini strategically for exploration phases only.

faq.question: Does this skill work with other AI coding tools?
faq.answer: The framework focuses on Claude Code and Gemini CLI but the decision methodology (size, task type, reasoning depth) applies to any AI development tool.

faq.question: What if my project requirements change mid-workflow?
faq.answer: Re-run the assessment using the six-question framework. The framework is iterative; switch tools if analysis shows different needs emerge.
